text: (bright music)

- I think everything that
I've done throughout my life,

I've been really
interested in doing things
that are exceptionally hard.
I thought it's something different,

it's something challenging,
and I love to challenge myself,
so I went and gave it a shot.
I'm Eric Peck, and I'm the CEO
and Co-founder of Swoop Aero.
(clapboard claps)
I started my career as a pilot
of the Royal Australian Air Force,
two combat tours of the Middle East,

a huge amount of humanitarian
work across Southeast Asia.

Having flown the Hercules
all around the world,
it really opened my eyes to the the impact

that we could have in making
the world a better place.

One of the really interesting
things we discovered

was that the cost of healthcare
is no longer really driven
by the cost of the medication itself.

It was largely driven by
the cost of transporting it
to its final point of use.

And we thought the real
way to create a company
around this with the technology

was to take the 70 ton
Hercules that I used to fly,

my co-founders robotic
engineering experience

and smash them together
to build a 25 kilo,
3D printed, autonomous aircraft,
and then use software to automate

all the processes that
sit around an aircraft,

so instead of having 70 people
looking after one aircraft,
like we did when I flew the Hercules,

we've got one person
looking after 70 aircraft,
and that's when Swoop Aero was born.

The story of real human impact
that sticks with me the most

is the first emergency
delivery we ever did.
We got a call at 9:00 in the morning
that a mother had just given birth
but had post-birth complications.
We need oxytocin delivered

to the south end of the
island for the mother.

If she has to catch the boat
nine hours up to the hospital,
there's a good chance she won't make it,
and the helicopter isn't available
to take her back to the main island.

We need a decision within
the next half an hour,

or she'll have to get on
the boat and give it a shot.
We set the aircraft down there
and just under 30 minutes later,
the aircraft landed in the village,

the medication was supplied,
and the mother was fine.
That story really defines why we do
what we do at Swoop Aero.
(bright music continues)
One of the unique things about Swoop Aero

is that we built our entire
technology stack from day one

to focus on operating a
global fleet of aircraft,
and it had to be a system

that the aircraft could
fly anywhere in the world.

They could be operated
from anywhere in the world
with nothing more than an iPad.
And by leveraging the AWS Cloud,
we were able to build a data lake,
full of all the flight data

from every single one of
the aircraft in the fleet
over the tens of thousands of flights
that we've done all around the world.
And so we're excited about a future

where every part of the world
has a new infrastructure layer

that is in fact invisible,
delivering supplies,
moving products and saving lives.
I think if you've got a big idea,
and you're ready to make the jump,
the one thing or the one piece of advice

that I would give to
you is to be fearless.

You're gonna have a lot of
people say, "It's not possible."
You're gonna have a lot of doubts
around whether you can do it,
and you've gotta be fearless
and move ahead to make it happen.
(bright music continues)
